title: Grade 7 English Language Arts
teaser: The overarching focus for all modules is on building students’ literacy skills as they develop knowledge about the world.

children.title: A Long Walk To Water
children.teaser: Students read A Long Walk to Water, study the Sudanese Civil War, and analyze character and point of view.

children.title: Culture, Time, Place, And Identity
children.teaser: Students examine different perspectives in A Long Walk to Water, supported by background text on the Sudanese Civil War

children.title: Unit Introduction: A Long Walk To Water
children.teaser: Module introduction through a map of South Sudan in the central text, A Long Walk to Water

children.title: Close Reading Strategies Used In The Central Text
children.teaser: Learning close reading strategies used in the Central Text throughout the model.

children.title: Inferring About Character
children.teaser: Analyzing and Discussing Points of View (Chapter 2)

children.title: Establishing Structures For Reading
children.teaser: Gathering Evidence about Salva’s and Nya’s Points of View (Reread Chapters 1 and 2)

children.title: Practicing Structures For Reading (Chapter 3)
children.teaser: Gathering Evidence about Salva’s and Nya’s Points of View (Reread Chapter 3)

children.title: Building Background Knowledge
children.teaser: The Lost Boys of Sudan

children.title: Practicing Structures For Reading (Chapter 4)
children.teaser: Gathering and Using Evidence to Analyze Salva’s and Nya’s Points of View (Chapter 4)

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment
children.teaser: Gathering and Using Evidence to Analyze Points of View in A Long Walk to Water (Chapter 5)

children.title: World Café To Analyze And Discuss Points Of View (Chapters 1–5)
children.teaser: Students use a text-based discussion protocol to revisit chapters 1-5.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: Reading For Gist
children.teaser: The Dinka and Nuer Tribes Until the Mid-1980s (“Sudanese Tribes Confront Modern War” Excerpt 1) (Version 1)

children.title: Building Background Knowledge: The Dinka And Nuer Tribes
children.teaser: Building background knowledge: using text based evidence and vocabulary to support analysis.

children.title: Building Background Knowledge About Sudanese Tribes
children.teaser: The Dinka and Nuer Tribes Until the Mid-1980s (“Sudanese Tribes Confront Modern War” Excerpt 2)

children.title: Citing Evidence In Writing
children.teaser: Citing evidence in writing through gathering and using evidence in a full response to constructed questions.

children.title: End Of Unit Assessment
children.teaser: Identifying Perspective and Using Evidence from Informational Texts about the Dinka and Nuer Tribes

children.title: Survival In Challenging Environments
children.teaser: Students complete A Long Walk to Water, and synthesize informational texts on the topic.  Culminates with analysis essay.

children.title: Theme
children.teaser: Students learn about the concept of theme

children.title: Routines
children.teaser: Students are introduced to classwork and homework routines

children.title: Practicing Note-Taking Routines
children.teaser: Students practice discussion and note-taking routines

children.title: Theme And A Long Walk To Water
children.teaser: Students continue to work with the theme of survival in A Long Walk to Water

children.title: Juxtaposition
children.teaser: Using Routines for Discussing A Long Walk to Water and Introducing Juxtaposition (Chapters 9 and 10)

children.title: Comparison Of Accounts
children.teaser: Students compare historical accounts of the Sudanese civil war to the novel.

children.title: Author's Use Of Alteration
children.teaser: Students analyze the author's use or alteration of historical information in the novel.

children.title: Analyzing Theme And Characters
children.teaser: Students use a text based discussion protocol to analyze theme and characters in the novel.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment
children.teaser: The Mid-Unit 2 Assessment, which evaluates students’ ability to explain how and why historical facts were altered by the author

children.title: Introducing Essay Prompt
children.teaser: Factors for Survival in A Long Walk to Water

children.title: Analyzing A Model Essay: “Challenges Facing A Lost Boy Of Sudan”
children.teaser: Students are introduced to a model essay in A Long Walk to Water.

children.title: The Rubric
children.teaser: Students look at the Expository Writing Evaluation rubric

children.title: Analyzing A Model Essay
children.teaser: Students analyze the model essay to learn about how details are used to support a claim.

children.title: Evidence To Support A Claim
children.teaser: Students begin to select evidence for supporting the claim to plan their body paragraphs

children.title: Writing The Body
children.teaser: Students write their planned body paragraphs.

children.title: Introduction And Conclusion
children.teaser: Students write their introduction and conclusion paragraphs for their literary analysis.

children.title: Performance Task Introduction
children.teaser: Students are introduced to their performance task for the module

children.title: Gathering Evidence
children.teaser: Students gather textual evidence from both the texts to prepare their poems

children.title: Revision
children.teaser: Students revise their literary analysis essays based on teacher feedback.

children.title: Culminating Project: Voices From Southern Sudan
children.teaser: Students create a two-voice poem inspired by the characters in the text.

children.title: Comparing Experiences
children.teaser: Students analyze point of view by considering how comparing and contrasting Salva’s and Nya’s experiences

children.title: Planning The Poem
children.teaser: Students plan their two-voice poem.

children.title: Model Poem
children.teaser: Students read a model poem focusing on how the author of the poem used evidence.

children.title: Peer Critique Of Poems
children.teaser: Students engage in a peer critique session focusing on use of evidence in their poems.

children.title: Evidence For Analysis
children.teaser: Students read and analyze several text excerpts and select strong evidence to support their analysis.

children.title: Presenting The Poems
children.teaser: Students present their two-voice poems

children.title: Working With Evidence: Working Conditions Then And Now
children.teaser: Students explore historical and modern working conditions, analyzing how people, settings, and events interact and how an author develops a central claim.

children.title: Working Conditions In Industrializing America
children.teaser: Students study how plot, character, and setting interact in literature through the novel Lyddie.

children.title: Gallery Walk: Working Conditions—Then And Now
children.teaser: Students preview and connect the case studies that compose the module.

children.title: Launching Lyddie
children.teaser: Students analyze how the plot, setting, and characters in Lyddie interact.

children.title: Modeling Entry Task, Reading Notes, And Reading Strategies For Lyddie
children.teaser: Students become familiar with the protocols for reading Lyddie.

children.title: Close Reading To Learn About Lyddie's Character
children.teaser: Students analyze how plot, character, and setting interact in Lyddie.

children.title: Analyzing Lyddie
children.teaser: Students engage in character analysis of Lyddie using evidence from the text.

children.title: Understanding Lyddie
children.teaser: Students begin to focus on working conditions in the mill and how they affect Lyddie.

children.title: Analyzing Word Choice: Understanding Working Conditions In The Mills
children.teaser: Students continue to focus on working conditions in the mill and how they impact Lyddie.

children.title: Analyzing Textual Evidence: Working Conditions In The Mills
children.teaser: Students complete the Working Conditions in Lyddie: Textual Evidence note-catcher.

children.title: Mid-Unit Assessment About Working Conditions In The Mills
children.teaser: Students use evidence to support their claims.

children.title: To Sign Or Not To Sign
children.teaser: Students use Odell's evidence based claims material to prepare an argument.

children.title: To Sign Or Not To Sign: Gathering Evidence
children.teaser: Students gather evidence to support their position regarding whether Lyddie should sign the petition

children.title: Crafting The Argument
children.teaser: Students synthesize the evidence they have gathered and begin forming their argument.

children.title: Writing The Argument
children.teaser: Introducing the Writing Prompt and Model Essay

children.title: Decision Point: Which Claim To Argue
children.teaser: Students continue to gather evidence and begin to write their argument, choosing the most compelling claim.

children.title: A Model Argument
children.teaser: Students analyze the model argument to better understand how to craft their own successfully.

children.title: Writing An Argumentative Essay: Planning The Essay
children.teaser: Students start a Writing Improvement Tracker.

children.title: Writing An Argumentative Essay: Peer Critique
children.teaser: Students evaluate other students' arguments.

children.title: End Of Unit Assessment
children.teaser: Part 1: Drafting the Argumentative Essay

children.title: Who Is Lyddie
children.teaser: Students engage with questions of identity, independence and freedom.

children.title: End Of Unit Assessment

children.teaser: Students use their knowledge of water to tackle an article on desalination

children.title: Cascading Consequences
children.teaser: Students study the consequences of choices around water management

children.title: Stakeholders
children.teaser: Students view the research they have organized in their charts through the lens of stakeholders

children.title: Preparing For Fishbowl And Writing
children.teaser: Students evaluate their evidence in preparation for a fishbowl and the writing in Unit 3

children.title: Sharing The Learning
children.teaser: Students share their learning in class discussion before committing to a position

children.title: Fishbowl Transition
children.teaser: Students collectively process their thinking around solutions to water management

children.title: Processing Thinking Through Visual Display
children.teaser: Students think critically about next steps and their visual display

children.title: End Of Unit Assessment
children.teaser: Students are assessed on speaking skills

children.title: The Extended Writing Process
children.teaser: Students analyze a model position paper and plan, write and revise their own.

children.title: Argument Essay Introduction
children.teaser: Students begin the process of planning their essay.

children.title: Independent Reading Check-In
children.teaser: Students participate in an independent reading check-in

children.title: Body Paragraphs
children.teaser: Students process their body paragraphs with a partner to articulate and solidify their ideas.

children.title: Talk-Through
children.teaser: Students summarize the entire paper for two peers.

children.title: Drafting
children.teaser: Students write the draft of their position paper about sustainable water management.

children.title: Capstone
children.teaser: Students step back and take an evaluative approach to the book they have completed

children.title: End Of Unit Assessment (Part 1)
children.teaser: Revising Claims and Evidence based on Feedback

children.title: End Of Unit Assessment (Continued)
children.teaser: Continue Revising Vocabulary and Conventions based on Feedback

children.title: Finishing The End Of Unit Assessment
children.teaser: Final Draft of Position Paper and Reflection on the Writing Process

children.title: Final Performance Task
children.teaser: Sharing Visual Representations of Position Papers

children.title: Developing Core Proficiencies Curriculum
children.teaser: These units model instruction and provide flexible materials to use and adapt for a variety of contexts.

children.title: Reading Closely for Textual Details Units
children.teaser: "We reckoned now that we were at the Pole"

children.title: The eternal silence of the great white desert.
children.teaser: Students analyze visual-based texts.

children.title: It was as though he had just heard his own sentence of death.
children.teaser: Students read and analyze informational texts.

children.title: the bitter wind searching every opening in the clothing
children.teaser: Students read, analyze, and compare texts.

children.title: The worst has happened, or nearly the worst.
children.teaser: Students read and analyze three related texts.

children.title: It seems a pity, but I do not think I can write more.
children.teaser: Students learn the characteristics of an effective text-based discussion.

children.title: Making Evidence-Based Claims
children.teaser: California Commonwealth Club Address, Cesar Chavez

children.title: Living Under Savage Conditions
children.teaser: Students learn the elements of making evidence-based claims.

children.title: We Organized!
children.teaser: Students develop the ability to make evidence-based claims.

children.title: California Grapes
children.teaser: Students organize evidence to develop and expand claims.

children.title: Our Accomplishments Cannot Be Undone
children.teaser: Students express evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: La Causa
children.teaser: Students express global evidence-based claims in writing.

children.title: Researching to Deepen Understanding
children.teaser: Water

children.title: Initiating Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 1, students will have identified an Area of Investigation and developed Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Gathering Information
children.teaser: By the end of Part 2, students will have assessed the main common sources and gathered notes about the information in the texts.

children.title: Deepening Understanding
children.teaser: By the end of Part 3, students will have a series of evidence-based claims addressing their Inquiry Questions.

children.title: Finalizing Inquiry
children.teaser: By the end of Part 4, students will have an analyzed body of research addressing their Inquiry Questions from which to develop and communicate an evidence- based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Developing And Communicating An Evidence-Based Perspective
children.teaser: By the end of Part 5, students will have an organized body of research and have written an evidence-based perspective on the Area of Investigation.

children.title: Building Evidence-Based Arguments
children.teaser: "Doping Can Be that Last 2 Percent"

children.title: The use of enhancement ‘substances’ for sporting events dates back to the ancient Greeks and ancient Maya.
children.teaser: Students understand an issue as a context for various perspectives, positions, and arguments.

children.title: The drugs are illegal, they’re harmful, and they’re cheating.
children.teaser: Students analyze the position, evidence, and perspective of arguments.

children.title: At their best, sports can embody the virtues of teamwork, hard work, and integrity
children.teaser: Students evaluate arguments and synthesize what they have learned.

children.title: This is about more than safeguarding fair play – it’s about saving lives.
children.teaser: Students establish evidence-based claims as a premises for a logical argument.

children.title: What do I know?
children.teaser: For students, writing is a key means of asserting and defending claims, showing what they know about a subject, and conveying what they have experienced, imagined, thought, and felt.
